overview.title: Frameworks Overview
overview.description: The Global Governance Frameworks provides a comprehensive approach to addressing complex global challenges through interoperable governance systems. Explore our documentation to discover principles, implementation strategies, and practical applications.

quickAccess.title: Explore the Frameworks Documentation
quickAccess.description: Access detailed documentation on principles, implementation guides, case studies, and resources.

implementationFrameworks.title: Implementation Frameworks
implementationFrameworks.description: Domain-specific frameworks organized by priority tiers, from foundational reforms to visionary governance models. Each framework provides detailed implementation guidance for its respective area.
implementationFrameworks.roadmapDescription: The frameworks are organized into five tiers representing a logical progression from addressing immediate crises to enabling long-term flourishing. This structure provides a clear implementation roadmap where foundational reforms create the stability needed for more advanced governance innovations.

gettingStarted.title: Start Your Implementation Journey
gettingStarted.description: Ready to implement these frameworks in your context? Our implementation guides provide step-by-step approaches, decision allocation tools, and case studies to help you get started.

0.title: Tier 0: Global Institutional Reform
0.description: This foundational tier serves as the prerequisite for all others. It is the operating system upgrade for global governance, focusing on the core rules, bodies, and legal frameworks that make coordinated international action possible.

1.title: Tier 1: Urgent Global Stability & Justice
1.description: This tier includes the most urgent domains of global governance—areas where failure to act can lead to irreversible harm, large-scale human suffering, or systemic collapse.

2.title: Tier 2: Systems for Long-Term Thriving
2.description: Tier 2 domains are foundational systems that enable sustainable human flourishing over time. They include governance of technology, finance, education, urban development, and employment.

3.title: Tier 3: Equity, Culture & Future Generations
3.description: This tier focuses on ensuring inclusion, preserving diverse heritages, and representing those often overlooked—such as youth, Indigenous peoples, rural communities, and future generations.

4.title: Tier 4: Visionary & Meta Governance
4.description: The fourth tier includes forward-looking and systemic domains of governance, addressing the deeper architecture of coordination, meaning-making, and planetary stewardship.

tier.noFrameworks: No frameworks defined for this tier yet.

intro.title: Introduction to Meta-Governance
intro.paragraph1: The world has numerous governance experiments happening at different scales, but they often operate in isolation. The Global Governance Frameworks provides patterns and interfaces that allow these diverse systems to interoperate.
intro.paragraph2: Our approach is not to create a single model of governance, but rather to build the infrastructure that enables many models to coexist, communicate, and evolve together.

emergingExamples.title: Emerging Possibilities in Action
emergingExamples.intro: Around the world, we're seeing promising examples of successful transnational governance in action. These real-world initiatives demonstrate what's possible when we create systems for cooperation across boundaries:

examples.title: Climate Action Networks
examples.description: Networks of cities collaborating directly on climate initiatives, sharing resources and knowledge across national boundaries. The C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group connects 97 cities representing over 700 million citizens to take bold climate action.

examples.title: Digital Democracy Platforms
examples.description: Software frameworks like Decidim and vTaiwan that enable large-scale citizen participation in policy development, creating new models for responsive governance beyond traditional representative structures.

examples.title: Transnational Commons Management
examples.description: Cooperative frameworks for managing shared resources that cross borders, from water systems to digital infrastructure, demonstrating how communities can self-govern across traditional boundaries.

examples.title: Regional Cooperation Frameworks
examples.description: Initiatives like the Nordic Council that enable diverse nations to collaborate while maintaining cultural autonomy and sovereignty, showing how cooperation can strengthen rather than diminish local identity.

techEnablers.title: Technological Enablers
techEnablers.intro: New technologies are making transparent, participatory global coordination possible at scales and speeds previously unimaginable:

enablers.title: AI for Transparent Decision-Making
enablers.description: AI systems that can process vast amounts of policy data, model impacts, and make decision processes understandable to citizens. These tools can help balance expert knowledge with democratic oversight, ensuring technical complexity doesn't become a barrier to participation.

enablers.title: Blockchain for Accountability
enablers.description: Distributed ledger technologies creating tamper-proof records of decisions, resource allocations, and policy implementations. These systems enable trust without requiring centralized authority, making transparent governance possible across diverse jurisdictions.

enablers.title: Digital Translation & Cultural Context
enablers.description: Advanced language models breaking down communication barriers between governance systems, enabling not just word-for-word translation but cross-cultural understanding of governance concepts and values.

enablers.title: Participatory Sensing Networks
enablers.description: Citizen-operated monitoring systems for environmental conditions, resource usage, and policy outcomes. These networks distribute both the work and the authority of governance, creating shared empirical foundations for decisions.

bottomUpApproaches.title: Bottom-Up Meets Institutional Evolution
bottomUpApproaches.intro: Effective global governance requires both grassroots innovation and institutional adaptation. Our frameworks focuses on the interfaces between these approaches:

principles.title: Mutual Recognition Protocols
principles.description: Standards that allow formal institutions to officially recognize and interact with community-led governance initiatives, creating bridges between traditional and emerging models.

principles.title: Sovereignty-Preserving Integration
principles.description: Approaches that allow communities to participate in broader systems while maintaining their right to self-determination, ensuring global frameworks strengthen rather than override local governance.

principles.title: Knowledge Commons Development
principles.description: Shared repositories of governance innovations, case studies, and best practices that allow both grassroots experiments and institutions to learn from each other's experiences.

principles.title: Nested Accountability Structures
principles.description: Frameworks ensuring that institutions remain accountable to the communities they serve, while communities' decisions consider impacts beyond their boundaries.

bottomUpApproaches.conclusion: By focusing on these interfaces, we can create governance systems that combine the adaptability and contextual awareness of bottom-up approaches with the coordination capacity and stability of institutions.

interoperability.title: 1. Governance Interoperability Framework
interoperability.intro: This framework helps different governance systems connect and collaborate effectively:

items.name: Protocol Standards
items.description: How different governance systems can exchange information

items.name: Decision Boundary Mapping
items.description: Clarifying which decisions belong at which levels

items.name: Translation Mechanisms
items.description: How decisions in one governance context can be understood and implemented in another

items.name: Conflict Resolution Interfaces
items.description: How to manage disagreements between governance systems

operatingSystem.title: 2. Governance Operating System
operatingSystem.intro: The concept of a modular, evolvable "operating system" for governance:

items.name: Core Functions vs. Applications
items.description: Distinguishing fundamental governance processes from specific implementations

items.name: Interface Definitions
items.description: Standard ways for citizens to interact with governance

items.name: Modularity Principles
items.description: How to design governance components that can be swapped out without system-wide disruption

items.name: Governance APIs
items.description: Standardized ways for subsystems to communicate

learnMore.title: Dive Deeper into the Frameworks
learnMore.description: Ready to explore the complete documentation? Our comprehensive guides provide detailed implementation instructions, principles, case studies, and resources.

interconnection.title: Core Principles Interconnection
interconnection.description: This diagram illustrates how the thirteen constitutional principles work together as an integrated system. The principles are organized by function: governance structure (green), rights and environment (brown), resource and conflict management (gold), and evolution and integration (purple). Each principle connects to the central Global Governance Frameworks while also reinforcing and balancing other principles.
